intro: Acanthocalycium brevispinum, commonly known as the short-spined cactus, is a species native to the arid regions of South America. It is a low-growing, spineless cactus with a compact, globular shape. The plant produces vibrant yellow flowers during the spring and summer months. Its thick, fleshy stems store water, allowing it to survive in harsh, dry environments. It is often cultivated as an ornamental plant due to its unique appearance and resilience.

It is commonly found in the Chihuahuan Desert region, where it thrives in arid and semi-arid environments. This cactus is adapted to grow in rocky soils and can often be seen on limestone outcrops. It is a small, spiny plant that typically grows in open, sunny areas with minimal vegetation. Due to its limited range, it is considered a rare and endangered species in many parts of its habitat.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acanthocalycium brevispinum was mainly introduced to the southwestern United States and northwestern Mexico.
